column4: i just installed an ubuntu system, but during the install the root passwords didn't match, but the installer would not return to the first prompt, it was always "reenter" so i just finished it up. now i need to change it. just want to check what the way to change it in single user mode?
afaik alsaconf is not in ubuntu (not the default install, anyway)
no, root is disabled. use sudo
you can enable root with sudo if you so desire
the only user should be in the admin group, and the admin group should be in the sudoers file
yah, should be but isn't
are you in recovery mode on your ubuntu box?
you need to boot in recovery mode and fix /etc/sudoers
k. fix == ?
will i just be able to edit it?
in recovery mode, yes
thanks will try that.
you shouldn't be prompted for a password in recovery mode
how have you installed ubuntu? clean install?
clean install used the "expert no-hlt" at boot prompt
oh
i think non-default installs might do things differently re the root account
were you asked for a root password during install? (would kind've destroy the 'no-halt' thing, i guess...)

yes, but they didn't match, and the installer was only going to the second prompt, meaning my first typo was being compared to whatever i retyped. so i just finished the install assuming that i could change it in single user mode.
doh
is this something where the debian base makes a difference. (ie ability to change root in single)
my system doesn't ask for a password in single-user mode. You seem to have activated ultra-paranoid mode ;)
*nod*  well i'll give that a shot, cause short of reinstall, i can't think of any other way to do this.
